title.narrative: (901.2) CHILDREN'S RIGHTS TO BE BORN AND REMAIN FREE OF HIV

description.narrative: Children's Rights to be born and remain free of HIV - HIV testing and prevention among adolescents, EMTCT and support in care and treatment, including Procurement and Supply Management of ARVs available., which contributes to Adolescent Empowerment, Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Hiv Prevention, Treatment And Care Of Children Living With Hiv. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Critical bottlenecks for affordable health care, child survival and young child well being are removed

related-activity.ref: 575R/A0/10/901 (901) THRIVING : AFFORDABLE HEALTH CARE AND YOUNG CHILD WELLBEING

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Children's Rights to be born and remain free of HIV - HIV testing and prevention among adolescents, EMTCT and support in care andtreatment, including Procurement and Supply Management of ARVs available.

description.narrative: The HIV epidemic in EECA continues to increase, although significant progress has been made in prevention and care efforts and ensuring that children are born and remain HIV free. Around 70% of those receiving HIV tests each year in Europe are women, mainly because of antenatal screening. Timely identification of pregnant women with HIV is central to an effective PMTCT programme, and most European countries have policies for routine HIV screening within standard antenatal screening that takes place early in antenatal care. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:04/05/2022

title.narrative: By 2021, 8 countries in ECA have validated eMTCT HIV and congenital syphilis(61658)
